moves.1. e4: "1.e4 - Best by test!" ~The great Robert James Fischer
moves.1... c6: The Caro-Kann is an interesting opening that I have always wanted to learn. I seems like a very sturdy defense. I see why "Iron Tigran" liked it so much.
moves.2. d4 d5 3. exd5: The exchange variation, loved by Fischer as well.
moves.3... cxd5 4. Bd3: This move blocks out Black's light-squared Bishop.
moves.4... Nf6 5. Nc3 e6 6. Nf3 Be7 7. O-O:
Steps to opening well:
1) Get a pawn in the center.
2) Develop your a few pieces.
3) Castle
moves.9. Ne5: Gaining more control with my Knight's lovely outpost.
moves.10. Bxh7+ Nxh7 11. Qxd4: Now Black's King is easier of a target, and Black has a very bad Knight compared to my Knight that is in the center.
moves.11... Bf6 12. a4: Taking some space on the Queenside.
moves.15. Nb5: Now both my Knights are on nice outposts.
moves.15... Bxe5: Black sees that my Knights are too powerful, and is forced to give up the Bishop Pair.
moves.16. Qxe5 Qf6: This is the move that lost Black the game.
moves.17... Qxe5 18. Rxe5 Rac8 19. Nxe8 Rxe8: Now White is up materially and positionally.
moves.20. a5 bxa5 21. Bc5: Taking care of the pawns, Mafia Style. ;)
moves.21... a6 22. Rxa5 Nf6: Black tries to restation his troops.
moves.23. Re3 Ne4 24. f3 Nxc5 25. Rxc5: White no longer has any minor pieces, but two Rooks.
moves.25... Rc8 26. Rxc8+ Bxc8: It was a mistake for Black to give up his Rook.
moves.27. Rc3 Bd7 28. Kf2: The King is one of the most valuable tools in the endgame.
moves.28... Kf8 29. g4 g6 30. h4 Bb5 31. Rc7 d: I am now hoping to Queen that pawn.
moves.34... Be2 35. Kg4 d3: Here is one more mistake. Black has given up his only good pawn.
moves.36. cxd3 Bxd3 37. Kg5: Black can hardly stop the pawn now.
